SACRIFICE.❤️ A Poem About Letting Go Of The
Special Person in your life.

Adrift in a raging sea of emotions, on a voyage to nowhere.
On the horizon, to my rescue, a distant saviour approaches,
The sea calms in her wake,
Her calmness becomes my calm.

A lifeline thrown, a steady hand on the tiller,
We sail together towards tranquil waters,
A life saved,
A life indebted.

The contents of her thoughts laid out In orderly rows,
Suddenly, & without warning, a whirling dervish invades,
Scattering the order, creating unwanted disorder.
The pureness of her thoughts coated with detritus.

One life ascending, one life decending,
The Yin & Yang of life
One life lived,
One life, a delicate orchid yet still to bloom.

To ensure its longevity,
The bloom craves care & nurturing
A calm, protective atmosphere will ensure her success.
Without distracting my friend from her chosen path.

oooooooooooooooo

Just broke up with my first girlfriend, and I'm almost 17 years old. We hadn't even been together for a year. Anyways, she invited me over to her house for her birthday, and it was honestly the most fun I'd had in years. I loved spending time with her, I loved *her*. But almost immediately after she started acting weird. A week goes by and she tells me that she feels like there's a problem in the relationship. She doesn't know anything about it other than it's there. I try everything to try to fix it, but no luck. She was, well... She was great. She set a really high bar for my next girlfriend, one so high that I'm not sure someone else could meet. I don't generally cry, but my eyes are sore from how much I have been lately. I just don't know what to do. Everything seemed so... perfect, until it wasn't. I know I'm only 16, but I had plans to stay with her as long as I could. Maybe not marriage (statistically improbable), but at least until senior year. It's rough, man. I just feel so lost.

Here's the subsidiary problem that underlies the whole treatment.

When you are suffering from emotional pain, no one wants to be around you. Because, you will most likely talk about your emotional pain, and suffering in a selfish way (IE. what happened to you, how no one gets you, etc...). Thus, alienating yourself from further social support, creating more pain, and suffering.

It's like pouring salt on an open wound.

Best to not talk about it, but still go out with friends, family, and find support indirectly. Simply speak about it in an observant way, if you must, so that others can empathize with you, rather than sympathize with you.

"We all just want to fit in somewhere".
I am with you and I understand your point. But WHY? Answering a question by another question, solving a problem by triggering another problem is not a solution. Why I should get socialized to forgot myself and the last one who is gone?

We, at the end of the day, are another creature, like a bug, a fish, or a rabbit. We are the product of some neurons, veins, hormones and so on which themselves are the outcomes of inner-body interactions and outer world parameters. As a result, we think "to be is better than not to be" hence we want to survive, reproduce, avoid the death as much as we can, "move on", forget, and anything that increases the chance of a longer and less painful life.

Knowing that, why "moving on" should be considered as "normal and standard behavior"? Being normal, socialized, moving on, and so on aren't another name for the way neurons, veins, and hormones of the majority of humanity work? referring to these terms isn't just a way to sustain our society? isn't it to force the out-of-range samples (called other humans) into our systems? these terms and systems are for solving out-of-range samples' problem or "us", the normal samples' problem?

A rabbit never asks what is the point of all of this and an apple never asks why I am an apple and live in this way. But, good or bad, we reached a level of brain functioning that we can ask "wait a minute, but what is the point of all of this stuff"?! Let's face it: there is no "point" and bigger than that, the "point" itself and the itch for finding it out are misleading.

Maybe giving a standard, "a wise man" style, and the lab-based answer is not convincing for everybody. I am thinking maybe sometimes we should simply say "hey, there isn't an "answer" or we have no answer. This is the way it is, you could never be here but now here you are so live the life. And if you don't find all of these convincing, then it's your call, your life, your decision!"

Maybe sometimes just being honest with others about the unpleasant features that are part of "us", the pains that are with us, and the ache that partially is making us, can be more helpful.
Physical pain, and emotional might be similar, but emotional pain will always hurt more

I was heartbroken a couple weeks ago. She told me that she felt like she couldnt give me the time I deserved, with everything going on in her life. Even before then we didnt talk much so I never really got attached, as you should. It wasnt until recently that I found out she found someone else. First thing I did was well try to talk to her, which was probably one of the worst ideas. You know people change. So she was acting a whole differently. Saying that this would’ve never happened had my friends not been involved so much. This was hypocrite to say as most of the time her best friend would make her decisions. I really did love this girl, don’t get me wrong. First couple days I was sad. Then I though: If she was never sad about it, why should i? I surrounded myself with family and friends. Did things to get he off my mind. Accepted things and let her go. Im still going through it and still thinking about what I could’ve done to prevent this. The fact is, this was never love. When you love someone, you try to fix things and it should be unconditional. Yet she walked away so fast for me to believe it was love. Im 15 and I mean love is love, so I was sad. Yea theres more things to worry about like school and future goals, but seeing the person you trusted and loved the most walk away. Its really sad and heartbreaking. Feelings and people change wether its for the better or worse. If you’re going through one as well. Just appreciate the great memories you’ve made and learn from it. To grow as a better person. Not sure why I'm writing this. Maybe it will feel good to see it in writing. I got married when I was 18. Shortly thereafter we moved in together and our relationship quickly began to spiral down. It was a terribly toxic relationship for the both of us. However, I still loved her. After a year of living horrible lives together, she left me for another guy. It was literally from one week to the next. I was devastated. The scariest part was talking to her and trying to reason with her and looking in her eyes and realizing that this wasn't just another fight. It was really over this time. It's been a year and she's moved on, has a kid with that new guy. I think about it everyday. While I am no longer angry with her and see her side of things, I'm still deeply hurt by what happened. In the year since all of this happened. Not a day has gone by that I don't think about it.

i have non verbal learning disorder, it's an aspergers spectrum disorder in terms of relation. it's tough because of it i don't understand up to 75% of all non verbal communication, fitting in becomes extremely difficult because i'm consistently confused about how people feel about me, if i ACTUALLY have friends or if a girl REALLY likes me, its difficult because my brain isn't sure to what they feel and with the amount of people who don't speak straight forward or strictly use technology to communicate i feel lonely a lot. don't have friends and am a loner, i've learnt how to cope but i can definitely see when people who don't have what i do lose people and become lonely they in-veritably become broken. i've had to learn to enjoy being alone and be ok with myself so that it doesn't affect me as adversely as it could (like the reactions pointed out in this video)  those people who don't have what i do always seem to reach their lowest points when they are separated from those they love, yet it's funny to me because i've lost people, never really had any to begin with and in some weird way i've come to lose that feeling of broken heart completely. it could be because aspergers sufferers don't really feel empathy but in a way while my life is extremely lonely and i do things independently without fear of social ridicule.. sometimes i wish i could feel that loss for someone, feel what it even is to have people love me and to love someone back. it's an odd notion but at the same time.. haha maybe having NLD isn't all that bad.

I was heart broken once.
Me and him were together and I felt like I was actually in LOVE! I was about to tell him but he wasn't where we meet up. I went searching round and... Let's just say I lost him and my BFF (we were friends for nearly 10 years now) when I found them. I blocked both of them on all social networking sites and I couldn't concentrate properly so my work went down hill I was on my final warning at work, but then I thought I saw them (turns out just random people) and it made me stronger. I remembered how much they had hurt me and betrayed my trust so I got hard down at work, had parties, and had the time of my life, and all that time THEY weren't invited to come.
I'm not looking for attention or anything, I just wanted to tell you my story and how heartbreak can make you a stronger person.

P.S. please don't think I'm looking for attention because I'm really not
P.S.S. remember, don't lock everyone out after a heartbreak, stay with close friends and family and they will help you through it.

While it is true that we all experience heartbreak at some point in our lives, they say that the first cut is the deepest, therefore, any heartbreak after that will be less painful, so never give up on life, no matter how bad things may seem. Granted, emotional pain can seem like physical pain, but emotional pain is psychological, and once you're aware of that, once you step back and see the big picture, it becomes much easier to control and to get through. I'm saying this purely for the reason that I want to help those who are heartbroken or emotionally scarred. Also, while it may be true that people would rather have physical pain than emotional pain, it's important that your physical pain is NOT being caused by the one that you rely on for emotional support/want emotional support from.

Actually, emotional pain and physical pain are very different. Think of a time you were physically hurt (like a broken leg or scraped elbow) the wound is healed, the pain is gone. You can remember the wound, you remember you we're in pain, but you can't distinctly recall exactly what it felt like. Now think of a time you were emotionally hurt (like a bad breakup or a lost love one) and you can FEEL that pain again. It's like an emptiness in your chest, when you think about it you can feel it.

I agree that you shouldn't correlate happiness with someone's presence, but there's nothing wrong with surrounding yourself with people that care about you when you're going through an emotional devastation. People don't like being alone with their thoughts thinking there's no one else that cares about them and there's nothing 'irresponsible' about being with friends and family when you're upset. You're not around them because you feel unappreciated, you're with them because they comfort you.

You're right in the sense that you do have to love and be comfortable with yourself before you can appreciate any relationship with others. But surrounding yourself with others when you're heartbroken will HELP you realize that your happiness didn't depend on the individual. Humans are incredibly social, no one can function in isolation. We have a natural desire to share our experience with others, and we feel better when we do. Keeping all your emotions to yourself will only turn out poorly

Yes, everyone gets wisdom teeth. Before the days of regular dental care, it was extremely common for some of your teeth to fall out over the years. Your wisdom teeth are meant to make up for the ones that you already lost. But since we all take (relative) care of our teeth these days, most of us still have all of our teeth by the time wisdom teeth come into play. Unfortunately, a lot of us just don't have the room in our mouths for that many teeth, so they grow in wonky and have to be removed.
